**_Learning metrics_** ** _can help push your L &D; program in the right
direction. But given the advanced analytics functions now available on LMS
platforms, and the opportunity to integrate other HR data sources while
measuring your learning metrics, this space can be hard to navigate. In this
article, we decode how to measure the success of your learning and development
programs, and share which four metrics can help with this._**

![](https://images.hrtechnologist.com/images/uploads/native_assets_images/hcm_bg_5d83497b97cac.jpg)

### Human Capital Management (HCM) Suites for High-growth Enterprises: The
Ultimate Guide [Buyers Guide]

Your HCM System controls the trinity of talent acquisition, management and
optimization - and ultimately, multiple mission-critical performance outcomes.
Choosing the right solution for your organization....

[Download](https://assets.hrtechnologist.com/research/human-capital-
management-hcm-suites-for-highgrowth-enterprises-the-ultimate-guide-buyers-
guide-128468?tfso=150406&zd_source=native_assets)

Often, it can be difficult for HR practitioners to measure if their L&D;
programs are working. Unlike marketing or sales, there are fewer numbers to
reaffirm your program’s efficacy. As a result, you could be investing in
ineffective L&D; tracks – or struggling to gain buy-in from the C-Suite,
because you couldn’t demonstrate measurable ROI.

This is why it is so critical to deploy L&D; analytics in parallel with your
learning programs. These analytics uncover valuable insights into
participation rates, progress trends, the number of completed certifications,
drop-off areas, and missing links in your L&D; framework.

But unless you know exactly what to look for, it's easy to get lost in the
labyrinth of learning metrics, building exhaustive reports that fall short of
value generation.

That’s why it’s so important to first identify your learning and development
goals and link back analytics data for valuable insights.

**Learn More:**[ **The Employee Training Makeover You Can’t Afford to
Skip**](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-development/the-
employee-training-makeover-you-cant-afford-to-skip/)

## **What Does Data Analytics Mean in the Context of L &D;**

Analytics is the first step towards getting visibility into the metrics you
want to measure.

In the context of L&D;, analytics takes the vast data sets available in your
LMS and applies a layer of analysis and visualization to highlight key
metrics. This could include:

  * Which training sessions have been completed 
  * Which teams have completed a specific
  * How employees consume different types of L&D; content 
  * Courses that have been taken more than once

  
If you’re applying analytics to L&D;, there are few [learning
metrics](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-development/digital-
learning-metrics-you-should-measure/) to watch out for. Of course, this will
vary according to the nature of your business and its unique requirements. For
example, increased positive customer feedback is an excellent indicator of
learning effectiveness (and an easy-to-measure metric) if you’re responsible
for a contact center.

But apart from these company-specific nuances, your [L&D; analytics
](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-development/the-top-
learning-development-questions-solved-by-analytics/)and measurement model
should be centered on four key learning metrics.

**Learn More:[5 Key Learning Management System (LMS) Trends in
2019](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-development/five-key-
lms-trends-2019/)**

## **Measure these 4 Metrics to Evaluate L &D; Success**

In addition to standard analytics data such as course completion rates and
pace of competition, there could be other vital areas that are being ignored.
Here are four learning metrics, as described by Ashish Rangnekar, co-founder
and CEO of [BenchPrep](http://benchprep.com), an advanced online learning
program for professional education and certification organizations, directly
linked to the impact of your L&D; program.

### **1\. The cold, hard cost of training your employees**

  
Did you know that per-employee training investment is a clear marker of your
past program’s efficacy? Organizations often tend to train the same employees
for the same skill sets.

Unless your workplace is witnessing sweeping changes, the cost of L&D; per
employee should remain stable. It is not advisable to blindly invest simply
because you have detected a skills gap. If you have provided the same training
before, this could mean that the solution isn't working as expected.

Make costs a vital component in your L&D; analytics dashboard, taking stock of
changing spending patterns every month, and realigning your L&D; modules
accordingly.

### **2\. A rise – or a dip – in operational efficiency**

  
This holds true specifically for production-oriented or high-volume
businesses. Your learners should be able to handle higher throughput at work,
managing larger volumes within the same time. That's why this learning metric
is intertwined with [performance
management](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/performance-management-
hcm/what-is-performance-management/).

Data gathered from performance management systems will indicate how well a
learner can apply their newly acquired skill sets in the workplace.

Conversely, if the learning program is ineffective or irrelevant to the
employee’s daily work schedule, you could even notice a dip in efficiency
levels. The learner is distracted from their workday, redirected to training
in areas that are not relevant to their role. It is essential to nip such
instances in the bud, and promptly channel the employee in a different
direction.

**Learn More:** **[What is a Learning Management System
(LMS)?](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-development/what-is-
a-learning-management-system-lms/)**

### **3\. Progress for both the company and employee**

  
L&D; isn’t just meant to benefit your organization. The employee should be
able to gain a meaningful advantage from undertaking the L&D; course. Look for
an acceleration in their career progression pathway, movement into cross-
functional roles, and an increase in compensation. HR practitioners often
ignore this aspect of L&D;, considering their job to be over once employees
have been certified.

But that’s not really the case. It’s only when an employee is able to take
their learnings and convert it into a _personal_ value-addition that the
learning can be deemed useful.

The same idea is also applicable at the organizational level. For the dollars
that you invest during a particular period in L&D;, you should be able to
witness a corresponding jump in revenue.

Remember, this won’t always be in the form of a rising bottom line. Future-
readiness, more effortless transformation, and scalability into new areas are
also indirect contributors to your revenue.

### **4\. Your learner’s feedback on the instructor**

  
Ask your employees to regularly evaluate their instructors as well as the
software they are using. This learning metric will indicate how satisfied your
learners are with the L&D; experience.

It’s important to note that learning in the workplace should be fun and
engaging – not just another responsibility on a person’s work schedule. That’s
why methodologies like [gamification in
learning](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-
development/why-2019-will-be-the-year-of-gamification-in-corporate-learning/)
are becoming so popular, reinventing the learning process with clear
incentives and drivers. Leverage [pulse surveys
](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/employee-engagement/pulse-surveys-
vs-annual-surveys-which-is-a-better-measure-of-employee-engagement/)after
every L&D; track to understand if such interventions are necessary.

**Learn More:** **[A Career in Learning and Development: 10 Must-Have Skills
to Make It Big in 2020](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-
development/skills-for-a-career-in-learning-and-development/)**

## **Getting Started with Learning Metrics – The Way Forward**

Fortunately, most LMS solutions come with built-in analytics to answer common
questions around L&D; effectiveness. However, to gain a holistic picture of
employee development, you need to integrate L&D; analytics with your broader
HR data landscape. Performance management, retention/attrition rates,
compensation, and employee engagement all have a role to play.

Here’s what we recommend:

  * Take stock of your organizational goals and identify which metrics (learning as well as other areas) are contributing factors.
  * Integrate your data sources, keeping an eye on [data quality](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/digital-transformation/6-questions-you-need-to-ask-about-your-hr-data-quality/).
  * Apply a visualization layer to create a comprehensive overview.
  * Realign L&D; as per the learning metrics mentioned above, and review the results using analytics.

  
L&D; is a critical component when offering employees a refreshed value
proposition. So, you must ensure that any L&D; program reaches its intended
goal without becoming part of the organizational “white noise.”

Your best bet to making this happen is to link L&D; with clear learning
metrics – numbers, graphical representations, dashboards, and razor-sharp
insights, which leave no room for conjecture or abstraction.

These metrics are your secret weapon to ensure that L&D; programs are accepted
and appreciated by both employee and employer.

company? __Let us know on_[

# Readers Choice 2019: Time and Attendance Management System

BIPO Service has been named the Gold Award winner of the Best HR Tech - Time
and Attendance Management System Readers Choice Award in 2019.

By: [HRM Asia Newsroom](https://hrmasia.com/author/hrmasia/ "Posts by HRM Asia
Newsroom") | November 30, 2019

Topics: [Employee Experience](https://hrmasia.com/category/topics/employee-
experience/) | [HR
Technology](https://hrmasia.com/category/topics/hrtechnology/) |
[News](https://hrmasia.com/category/main/news/) |
[Singapore](https://hrmasia.com/category/markets/singapore/) | [Southeast
Asia](https://hrmasia.com/category/markets/asean/)

![](https://hrmasia.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/DSCF0131-resized.jpg)

The adoption of automation in the HR department has become increasingly
important in today’s digital world. One of the areas sometimes overlooked is
time and attendance of employees. But this can be a big mistake, as it can
lead to lower growth and productivity.

There are new, automated systems that offer a range of new features to help
you keep track of time and attendance.

While sales are important, employers also need to understand the importance of
having modern and efficient systems that allow HR and other internal teams to
run effectively. The HRM Asia 2019 Readers Choice Awards recognises those HR
vendors who have the best tech when it comes to time and attendance management
systems.

Scooping our Gold Award this year was BIPO Service. Albert Liew, General
Manager of BIPO Singapore, said how ‘’incredibly honoured’’ he was to receive
the award. “Each vote and every award has given us a huge confidence boost!
These awards are especially meaningful because HRM Asia’s readers have made
that special effort to cast a vote for us and show their support.

“It really is an affirmation for BIPO,’’ he said.

[![](http://hrmasia.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/IMG_8084-resized-and-
cropped.jpg)](http://hrmasia.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/IMG_8084-resized-
and-cropped.jpg)The Silver award in this prestigious category was won by Times
Software. Rene Wong, Marketing Manager of Times Software (pictured, left), was
keen to thank her team along with the readers of HRM Asia. “These awards would
not have been possible without their votes and ongoing support,” she said.

Times Software has been investing in its HR solutions and it now has market-
leading features built around the core competencies of robustness,
flexibility, data security, high availability, ease of use and cost
effectiveness. These are supported by its excellent customer services team who
helped it achieve the win.

**BIPO Service**

BIPO is a leading one-stop human resources provider in Asia-Pacific, focused
on providing organisations with innovative ways to manage complex end-to-end
HR processes.

Through our cloud and mobile-based HR Management system as well as industry-
leading solutions such as Payroll Outsourcing, Attendance Automation, Business
Intelligence, HR Consulting, Recruitment & Business Process Outsourcing and
Flexible Employee Management, we help companies transform their HR operations
to and beyond their expectations, while achieving business goals related to
cost and profitability.

[www.biposervice.com](http://www.biposervice.com)

  |  |

**Times Software**

Times Software Pte Ltd is a privately owned, home-grown company, incorporated
in 1998.

As the industry leader with many years of experience in the HR, information
technology and finance sectors, we continuously achieve our mission to provide
excellent products and services to cater to the needs of our clients from all
industries.

Our core products are our comprehensive suite of award-winning TIMES Payroll
and cloud enabled HRIS applications. We also provide Payroll and HR
Outsourcing services, E-Portal services and custom HR solutions.

[www.timesoftsg.com.sg](http://www.timesoftsg.com.sg)

#  Paycom Announces Further Enhancements to Learning Management Software

December 09, 2019 09:15 AM Eastern Standard Time

OKLAHOMA CITY--([BUSINESS WIRE](https://www.businesswire.com/))--Paycom
Software, Inc. (“Paycom”)(NYSE: PAYC), a leading provider of comprehensive,
cloud-based human capital management software, today announced the rollout of
its proprietary Performance Evidence and Video Content Creator, two
enhancements to its learning management platform, Paycom Learning.

> “I am excited about these developments to Paycom Learning as we continue to
> add value for our clients and put HR technology in the hands of their
> employees,” said Chad Richison, Paycom’s founder and CEO. “We understand the
> impact learning and development programs can have on a company’s overall
> strategy and growth, and these two features bring a whole new approach to
> how companies can implement, measure and report on key initiatives.”

A 2019 PricewaterhouseCoopers study reveals one of CEOs’ top three concerns is
the unavailability of key skills in the workforce, which threatens business
growth. As companies continue to struggle through talent shortages driven by
skills deficiencies, Paycom’s Performance Evidence and Video Content Creator
can help organizations develop their workforce to meet rapidly evolving
business needs.

With Performance Evidence, clients can create a lesson tool that allows their
employees to demonstrate knowledge and mastery of a specific skill to confirm
they are truly grasping the course material. Managers or trainers then can
provide direct input about the employee’s performance, creating a true
feedback loop that promotes employee development.

Additionally, the Video Content Creator allows subject-matter experts to share
knowledge across the company by empowering them to create, upload and
distribute engaging microlearning content quickly and easily. Clients can
simply grant access to the appropriate individuals by enabling the feature in
their user profile. The user can then record their own training video, upload
it into the system in their preferred video file type, and add accompanying
materials and questions to test the viewer’s knowledge.

And there’s good reason why eight out of 10 learning and development
professionals favor microlearning. Research from the _Journal of Applied
Psychology_ reveals the approach is more efficient than traditional courses
and improves the knowledge transfer by 17%, meaning newly learned skills are
more likely to be retained and used in the workplace.

Both Paycom Learning enhancements provide clients with a number of
customization tools that address access, time restrictions, reporting
capabilities and much more. These new features come on the heels of other
major 2019 developments like Ask Here™ and Direct Data Exchange™, as Paycom
continues to advance its focus to drive ROI for its clients.

**About Paycom**

As a leader in payroll and HR technology, Oklahoma City-based Paycom redefines
the human capital management industry by allowing companies to effectively
navigate a rapidly changing business environment. Its cloud-based software
solution is based on a core system of record maintained in a single database
for all human capital management functions, providing the functionality that
businesses need to manage the complete employment life cycle, from recruitment
to retirement. Paycom has the ability to serve businesses of all sizes and in
every industry. As one of the leading human capital management providers,
Paycom serves clients in all 50 states from offices across the country. For
more information, visit
[Paycom.com](https://cts.businesswire.com/ct/CT?id=smartlink&url=https%3A%2F%2Fpaycom.com%2F&esheet=52141873&newsitemid=20191209005141&lan=en-

# Degreed and LearnUpon Partner to Unify Best-in-Class Learning Experience and
Learning Management Systems

## Deep integration of Degreed’s learning experience platform and LearnUpon’s
learning management system offers joint customers a streamlined learning and
development solution

__ __ __ [
__](https://plus.google.com/share?url=http://www.globenewswire.com/news-
release/2020/02/11/1982744/0/en/Degreed-and-LearnUpon-Partner-to-Unify-Best-
in-Class-Learning-Experience-and-Learning-Management-Systems.html) __ __Email
[ __Print Friendly ](/news-release/2020/02/11/1982744/0/en/Degreed-and-
LearnUpon-Partner-to-Unify-Best-in-Class-Learning-Experience-and-Learning-
Management-Systems.html?print=1 "Print") __Share

_February 11, 2020 00:00 ET _ | **Source:** Degreed

PLEASANTON, Calif., Feb. 11, 2020 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) --
_[Degreed](https://www.globenewswire.com/Tracker?data=g8ZbQFDFN0NdZp37MQQs00_fb4nd6Uilx1UkKb8wJ5_jdsbKKZLlRFo8J_h10M-MO47oBIZWzMjmjdCz2D5E5Q==
"Degreed")_ , the workforce learning experience and skill-tracking platform,
and
_[LearnUpon](https://www.globenewswire.com/Tracker?data=os3M7d2AXoSB38Ilg4NyAoBI8x2l46K1aDC40R6dbmDlNC2ZtApgJ0APcHMOEBWlFDVCcc5w-JHB3E2irrcqqQ==
"LearnUpon")_ , an award-winning learning management system, announced a new
strategic partnership that offers the power of both SaaS products through a
single solution.  

With LearnUpon, companies can create, manage, and track formal workforce
learning, such as mandatory or optional training. Degreed provides a single
app where workers can find, access, and track formal training, like courses
built in LearnUpon, along with informal learning resources, like videos,
podcasts, or articles they use in the flow of work.

LearnUpon’s powerful, easy-to-use LMS makes the learning administrator’s job
easier while Degreed’s innovative learning experience platform (LXP) amplifies
employee engagement with learning by connecting development opportunities to
daily work habits and longer-term career goals. Combined, they address the
growing challenges of agile creation and adoption of learning resources.

**Key benefits of the Degreed + LearnUpon partnership include:**

  * **One unified learning experience**. Users and admins can search, access, and track all relevant learning through one solution.
  *  **One vendor to manage**. Clients can get the most admin-friendly LMS and the most advanced LXP with a single procurement process.
  *  **One support system**. Clients and their end-users get committed, knowledgeable support from customer-obsessed experts on both platforms.

“As businesses look to right-size their learning technology ecosystems, this
partnership brings together a best-in-class LMS and the industry’s leading LXP
to provide an unrivaled learning experience for our joint customers,” said
Brendan Noud, CEO of LearnUpon. “Our combined solution simplifies learning
processes, for both admins and learners. It's easy to use, better integrated,
and our dedicated customer focus ensures that LearnUpon and Degreed’s teams
deliver an amazing customer experience."

With Degreed’s unified search, data-powered learning plans, and collaboration
tools, everyone can curate or crowdsource their own learning plans as easily
as they browse the internet. And through Degreed’s unique, embedded skill
ratings and analytics, and its _[new Total Talent
networks](https://www.globenewswire.com/Tracker?data=mQO2zHRZAhvTKE8vTnCmr0QOhUvxtCvLBCCpe7tq2b5M_DnQVdkw4wGTYuClctihLHH609gfYPG2Ny5zPmebBrAijmijgVHdO3oC5mb5otE6eWa0NC5VvTji4o_924Ls
"new Total Talent networks")_ , HR and business leaders gain new visibility
into the capabilities and gaps of their internal and external workforce.

“We’re not simply offering a seamless integration with LearnUpon—we’re also
providing a seamless buying process. Now Degreed can help clients streamline
their technology investments and vendor management without sacrificing on user
experience, product features, or innovation,” said Chris McCarthy, CEO of
Degreed. “Businesses need more than just an engaging learning experience. They
need tools that enable their learning and HR teams to adapt more quickly to
constantly shifting opportunities. That’s what Degreed + LearnUpon (as well as
our recent acquisition of Adepto) is all about.”

To learn more about how you can right-size your learning investments with
_[Degreed](https://www.globenewswire.com/Tracker?data=g8ZbQFDFN0NdZp37MQQs07GoIUNgHIgoj0hZQ63gE5eRmTvhPy4apO389O5C9xeQSeL_NMrf3dGpFBYltBa-
iQ== "Degreed")_ and
_[LearnUpon](https://www.globenewswire.com/Tracker?data=os3M7d2AXoSB38Ilg4NyAhn1QC5i_rsZCWzcqmKB0lTs9PNYq4iOeXvkqiKTYwVltakNP76TLrDzgZITQX29oA==
"LearnUpon")_ , click
_[here](https://www.globenewswire.com/Tracker?data=FLJ40jjidik76-ZncjnsSuhuZ34SlTBGICTk16iE7GPDPigRUi3NKMuVa40egQuBo4Bq5lyx5VVsY4sci2jLrA==
"here")_.

**About Degreed**

Degreed is the workforce upskilling platform for one in three Fortune 50
companies. We integrate and curate all the resources people use to learn —
including learning management systems and millions of courses, videos,
articles, books, and podcasts. Then we use behavioral and data science to
analyze everyone's skills, and to automatically personalize development based
on their jobs, strengths, and goals. Founded in 2012, Degreed is headquartered
in Pleasanton, California, with additional offices in Salt Lake City, New
York, London, Amsterdam, and Brisbane.

practical approach to learning. By combining industry-leading capabilities,
unmatched ease of use, and unrivaled customer support, organizations can
manage, track, and achieve their diverse learning goals—all through a single,
powerful solution. Trusted by over 1,000 customers worldwide, LearnUpon is one
of the fastest growing LMSs in the world. Founded in 2012, LearnUpon is

_**Welcome to the fifth episode of Succeeding with AI in HR. This edition of
AI in Learning and Development will provide you with an understanding of the
key applications of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in driving learning and
training initiatives, creating a culture of learning, boosting productivity
and morale and elevating the employee experience. You will also learn about
the key features, use-cases, and questions to ask before investing in an AI-
powered learning management system.**_

## **Table of Contents**

  * _**An Introduction to L&D; Today**_
  * _**5 Use-cases of AI in L&D;**_

## **An Introduction to L &D; Today**

Before we deep dive into the latest trends in the organizational learning and
development space, before we take stock of the changes that have been making
us question and reinvent learning as we know it and before we analyze how to
choose the right [learning management system (LMS)
](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-development/what-is-a-
learning-management-system-lms/)for our unique needs, let us acknowledge what
lies at the heart of every learning process: adaptation.

How adaptive an organization is today, determines how well it can thrive (and
not merely survive) in the years to come. **Going back to the basics, it
always helps to remember that learning is a relatively permanent change in
behavior that is brought about by experience and maintained through practice.
The operational phrase to pay heed to in that definition is " _relatively_
permanent".** It presupposes a certain level of dynamism and fluidity - of
change and possibilities. This holds true especially in our present times
where stagnation and complacency have no room given the pace of change!

**Hawley Kane, Head of Organizational Talent and Leadership Development at
Saba Software** talked to HRT about the biggest trend to watch out for in L&D;
today and said "Hands down we see the connection of learning to performance as
being the a-ha moment for L&D.; Here's the crux of it: **For high-performing
organizations, learning is not the outcome - it is the behavior that drives
performance**." She clarifies that learning and performance management do not
merely co-exist - they are dependent on one another. Thus, to deliver learning
experiences that move the needle on performance, talent leaders need to
empower employees to drive their own development with learning that is aligned
to individual, team and business goals.

Hawley adds, "By thinking in terms of business outcomes and focusing L&D;
programs on specific behaviors, skills, or competencies, you can solidify the
learning-performance connection to achieve the results that matter to your
business."

To talk about L&D; today without mentioning the impact of Artificial
Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML), would be a hollow discussion. The
impact of technology on learning is crucial since it works in a loop -
learning and technology power each other.

## **5 Use Cases of AI in L &D;**

The evolution of learning and the advancement of technology go hand-in-hand
and this interdependence demands that we look at the impact of technology on
organizational learning today, and the [use-cases of AI in L&D; to understand
how learning processes have been
transformed](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-
development/3-ways-ai-will-transform-learning-and-development/) and improved.

![5 Use Cases of AI in L&D](/images/ajax-loader.png)

Let's look at the five major use-cases of AI in organizational learning and
development.

### **1\. Deeper, Wider Analytics**

  
With AI, L&D; managers can make better sense of the data dump that comes with
all digital workplaces.  Deep data analysis creates new avenues for
reassessment and redesign of courses with far greater precision. Data can thus
become more than simply a repository and be looked at as a tool for
transformation. AI tools can help access depths of data not explored before
while also enabling the organization to navigate widths that could otherwise
be impossible. A recent Gartner report claims that by 2020, AI will create 2.3
million jobs while making1.8 million roles redundant. In an environment as
charged with change as that, data cannot be a mere fallback but rather, the
treasure of information needs to be the building blocks on which a culture of
continuous change can be built. **AI-powered learning processes could thus be
mined as the missing link between employee engagement, workforce productivity,
and business profitability.**

### **2\. Real-time Artificial Mentoring**

  
With AI, learning modules can now be a lot more interactive and powered by
natural communication. Conversational bots and engaging interfaces can
transform learning by making employees feel a lot more in the loop. AI
teaching assistants enable trainers in interacting with a wider employee base
while still adhering to each employee individually. Learning Management
Systems (LMS) can, therefore, be made more responsive and the quality of
answers to queries improved. It is thus no wonder that digital tutors that can
engage with employees in real-time are quackly gaining in popularity.
**Artificial mentors come with the very real benefits of a much more engaging
learning experience.**

### **3\. Augmented Content**

  
With the format of basic [learning and
development](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-
development/what-is-learning-and-development-objectives-strategy/) processes
having undergone an evolution, the content of learning modules need to change
as well. While creating content with the aid of subject matter experts is
essential, it could often be time-consuming. AI tools today are capable of
being trained to skim through tons of information, take out the most relevant
pieces of information and stitch it all together in a format that is human-
readable. Immersive, virtual reality (VR) enabled content not only engage
learners better but also ensure deeper internalization and more effective
application of learned skills and behavior. With fresher content created
faster, the shelf-life of learning courses can also be extended and while AI
still has a ways to go before being able to organically create and curate more
complicated learning programs, the journey has surely begun.

### **4\. Anytime-anywhere Access**

  
We live in a world of anytime-anywhere access to information. It is only
natural that employees expect the same level of access in learning processes.
This not only applies to millennials but to employees at large – they want to
be able to tune into relevant courses on-demand and AI-enabled LMS are making
that a reality by being able to track career journeys, map career paths and
predict learning and skilling needs at each stage of the journey. **In
addition to individual access, a smart, future-ready LMS system also needs to
cater to an inherently diverse workforce.** Are the systems available in
different languages, is the individual context of each employee taken into
consideration while tailoring the larger learning programs, how do employees
who have visual or auditory constraints interact with and gain from the
courses;, and do the L&D; program delivery and outcomes get smarter and better
over time with AI finding patterns of learning success?

### **5\. Meaningful Personalization**

  
AI can help enhance the learning experience by creating personalized content
and tests that speak to the individual. This goes a lot further than expecting
your employees to enjoy a one-size-fits-all training course. From product ads
that pop up on our screens to notifications and service suggestions that speak
specifically to us, we crave from personalized messages from our environment.
With learning too, **AI-enabled platforms that can engage a diverse range of
employees are more effective. This allows each employee to be on a meaningful,
personalized learning journey while growing collectively.**

## **Choosing the Right LMS**

Selecting the right Learning Management System (LMS) is as crucial to the
success of the organization as the selection of the right talent. With a
plethora of options available in a market that is crowded with LMS offerings,
how do you ensure that you’re making the right choice? Here’s a step-by-step
guide for you to keep in mind before taking the plunge. While you may already
be aware of these measures that help, it always helps to reiterate these
throughout the organization – especially to the team of L&D; managers who
would be taking the decision on selecting a learning management system or the
upgrades that needs to happen on the one that already exists.

![Choosing the Right LMS](/images/ajax-loader.png)

## **Know Your Needs**

Before you start even window-shopping for an LMS solution, ask yourself:

  1. Who is your target learner audience?
  2. What are the learning objectives?
  3. What are the skill-sets that need to be in focus and why?
  4. What is your end goal (it is not limited to just improving performance)?
  5. Would the training be imparted individually or simultaneously for the whole team?
  6. How flexible do the learning modules and the deployment models need to be?

  
Once you have the answer to the questions above, you are ready to embark on
the journey of finding a new LMS or an upgrade for the existing one. Learning
objectives and course logistics are always easier to ascertain before you
start weighing options.

## **Know Your Best-Fit**

To understand what would work best for you, the next stage involves delving
deep into technical considerations and limitations. It is not simply about
putting best practices to use, but rather to acknowledge the need for a best-
fit learning strategy.

**Dennis Budinich, Chief Culture Officer & SVP, Investors Bank, **shares that
**“** One of the biggest elements in identifying the right eLearning solution
is to take the time to understand how people learn. By catering your approach
to how an employee learns, employees are more likely to adopt these practices
into their daily lives. Adoption of these practices leads to behavioral
changes. This is something that is often missed by training and development
leaders.”

He adds “ **By focusing on the fundamental principles that support and enable
people to learn, adapt and practice, companies can set themselves up for
eLearning success for their employees.** ”

Once companies learn what principles work best for their employees, they know
exactly what to look for in an eLearning solution. Focus on how and if the
solution moves the needle as opposed to price points, ease of use, etc.
Employers should be more interested in how people learn as opposed to how to
train them with adoption and finding the right fit being the primary goal.

**Learn More:** **[What Is Human Resource Development (HRD)? Definition,
Functions, and Best Practices for Training
Program](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-development/what-is-
human-resource-development/)**

## **Know Your Feature Priorities**

With technology getting upgraded every day, the LMS market is evolving as well
as are the features that these solutions provide. But what are the features
that would work best for your organization? What are your “feature comforts”?
This is where you need to have a must-have, good-to-have and great-to-have
classification for your desired features.

**Hawley suggests that for an organization to upgrade to AI-enabled L &D; with
ease, “**Personalized content/recommendations are a critical element of the
modern user experience for any application (think Netflix, Spotify, etc.). As
the corporate learning market evolves to focus more on the experience that
modern users expect, AI and machine learning become even more strategic for
L&D; teams & leaders.” She adds that **the need is to expand and leverage even
deeper people insights to create “just for me” experiences, conversations and
connections that deliver "one to one" personal human interactions at a "one to
many" scale**. This is a key feature to keep in mind when shopping for new LMS
software. Your choice would also depend on discussion boards or forums,
test/assessment capabilities, enhanced security protocols, grading/scoring
processes to track progress, data tracking, and automated user functions like
notifications.

## **Know Your Growth Plans**

With choosing the right features and implementing a new Learning Management
System, you need to know where you are headed as an organization. These are
not steps that you are taking just for today. For strategically sound
decisions, the scope of amplifying the learning and its application in
addressing the future needs of the organization need to be kept in mind.

**Skip Marshall, HCM Technology Executive at DXC Technology** lists the three
main challenges that organizations face today when it comes to upgrading their
L&D; frameworks as follows:

**Planning a strategy:** Organizations need to start with business objectives
in mind.

**Breaking down silos:** All business stakeholders must be vested and believe
in the solution.

**Undergoing change management:** Change is an inevitable part of business. It
is important to view the speed of change as an opportunity to transition to
more user-friendly, flexible and inclusive learning systems. Obtain and
achieve key business stakeholder support across business groups, to help drive
the solution.

These points are true especially when it comes to gauging how adaptive your
chosen AI-enabled LMS will be in the future. Would it help you upgrade to the
next big thing after AI or be a deterrent to the next stages of evolution?
Finding a solution that enhances fluidity while helping you make the most of
immediate technology is a wise move.

**Learn More:** **[5 Key Learning Management System (LMS) Trends in
2019](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-development/top-lms-
trends/)**

## **Know by Experimentation**

**Catie Bull, Senior Marketing Manager at Intrepid** speaks of a few questions
that organizations need to keep in mind when choosing the right eLearning
solution:

  1. How easily does the technology help you reduce the time between designing and delivering training?
  2. How much can you do directly on the platform (creation, review, etc.) versus having to keep relying on external old-school learning development processes, which cause delays?
  3. Does this technology give you a way to help learners across multiple “moments of need” or just one?
  4. How much control does the technology give to the administrator/course creator vs. the learner themselves?
  5. How easy is it to make changes in response to real-time feedback?
  6. How much insight does the technology give you into learner behaviors so you can make changes based on usage and responses in real-time?
  7. What is not just the company’s level of technological expertise, but their level of expertise in learning experience design using technology?
  8. Can they make you better learning designers through the use of their online platform?  
A lot of these questions need to be answered in action and not in thought
alone. That is where experimentation comes in. Yes, buying the right LMS is a
big investment and while you cannot buy one just to see how your organization
reacts and adapts to it, you could do a trial run. Quite a few solution
providers do come with the option for a free trial.

## **Through the Looking Glass: What does the future hold for AI in L &D;?**

Next-generation learning tools include collaborative learning platforms, which
are more business-centric and individual-driven. Learner Experience Platforms
(LXP) focus closely on the quality of learner experience. Learning with next-
generation tools moves from the one-to-many classroom-type model to include a
one-to-many along with a many-to-many social and collaborative interaction
between learners, and moderators or subject matter experts as well. This
strengthens learning, heightens the sharing of insights, and surfaces tacit
institutional knowledge that all can be shared and iterated upon.

Catie says “ **By making the shift from learning to on-the-job application
simpler for the learner. Programs and tools which allow easy inclusion of
company context—the “why” behind all the “how”—bridge the gap between
knowledge and application back on the job**. They can also allow for
application on the job during the learning process, with assignments applying
concepts to real work products, with no gap.” She adds that collaborative
learning programs spaced out over a period of time also allow for reflection.
This is critical to really absorbing and synthesizing new material.

**Mike Begin, VP, Chief Technology Officer at Brainier Solutions** stresses on
the fact that “Early adoption of new technology usually comes with a high
price tag. In the case of AI, look for the features that are designed to
improve efficiency in L&D.; Features that provide your department the luxury
to be more strategic than tactical in their duties.” If you considered
acquiring or licensing technology and relevant content that is aligned with
your organization’s broader goals, the road ahead becomes simpler.

**The convenience of predictive search and recommendation engines make
searching more efficient. Also, personalized dashboards offer real-time
analytics of trends in your learning group to help you stay informed.**
Ultimately, these tools can help to recruit new talent and take calculated
risks with more confidence. By viewing technology as an enabler, organizations
can benefit from innovation in the learning, development and training space,
including advances in cloud computing, which has made it easier to manage
change with speed and dependability. At the heart of it all, remains the
ability and drive to adapt – to create a culture where employees are
comfortably aware of the fact that technology and skills will become redundant
even faster in the future, and are uncomfortable enough to never become
complacent – to keep learning, adapting and winning together.

**_Whether it’s a startup or an enterprise-level business, hiring and managing
talents is the most essential thing that an entrepreneur can do to ensure
long-term growth and stability. Since there’re many human resource software
options on the market today, we’ve developed a guideline for business owners
to help them choose the right talent management system, writes Alex Sokolov,
senior software engineer, iTechArt Group._**

![](https://images.hrtechnologist.com/images/uploads/native_assets_images/hcm_bg_5d83481487bf0.jpg)

### Human Capital Management (HCM) Suites for High-growth Enterprises: The
Ultimate Guide [Buyers Guide]

Your HCM System controls the trinity of talent acquisition, management and
optimization - and ultimately, multiple mission-critical performance outcomes.
Choosing the right solution for your organization....

[Download](https://assets.hrtechnologist.com/research/human-capital-
management-hcm-suites-for-highgrowth-enterprises-the-ultimate-guide-buyers-
guide-128468?tfso=150406&zd_source=native_assets)

Employees are the backbone and lifeblood of your business. They are also what
determines your overall success or failure as a company. Hiring the right
people and keeping them is the most important thing you can do to ensure long-
term growth and stability. But it can be extremely hard and time-consuming to
keep track of all things related to human resources - from recruiting and
hiring to employee development, career planning, mentoring and more.

Whether you have a large or small HR team or run a startup or enterprise-level
business, you need a talent management system (TMS) to help automate some of
the day-to-day tasks and free your staff to focus on growing the business.

There are many human resource software options on the market today, but before
you can choose the one that is right for you, you need to do a little research
and a lot of planning.

In this article, we’ll discuss what a talent management system is, why you
need one, and how to select the right one. Let’s get started.

## **What is talent management software anyway?**

A [talent management](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/strategy/what-
is-talent-management/) solution encompasses all of the activities involved in
hiring and retaining the best employees and staying one step ahead of your
competitors. It is designed to track an employee’s performance and engagement
with your company from the day they start to the day they retire. This
includes the following:

**Recruiting** \- A recruiting module helps hiring managers become aware of
the best candidates for each position and features easy solutions for job
postings, submissions, skills testing, and the entire interview process.

**Hiring** \- An automated TMS system can assist with offer letters,
background checks, e-signing of hiring documents and contracts, signing
bonuses, relocation expenses, and more.

**Onboarding** \- The[ onboarding
process](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/recruitment-onboarding/what-
is-new-employee-onboarding/) can be automated to provide corporate training
and presentations either electronically or in a physical office. This can be
done through a series of videos, a corporate intranet with special tools and
information for new hires, a FAQs database, mentoring scheduling, and anything
else that can help a new employee hit the ground running.

**Compensation and Performance Management** \- The TMS system can be utilized
to set employees’ pay grades, hiring levels, annual review scheduling and
tracking, career advancement, incentives, and provide management with a
360-degree view of an employee’s performance throughout their tenure with the
company.

**Continuing education and development** \- Through online or in-person
classes, continuing education and corporate e-learning programs can make it
easy for staff to enhance their skills and move up the corporate ladder. It
can also be an important asset when it comes to meeting governmental and legal
requirements for certifications in industries such as government, healthcare,
education, and more.

**Learn more:[How to Make the Talent Development Evolution Work for Your
Organization](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-
development/how-to-make-the-talent-development-evolution-work-for-your-
organization/)**

## **Why should business owners consider talent management software?**

One of the main purposes of an HR talent management software system is to
automate and streamline the entire hiring and nurturing process. It also
provides useful analytics and feedback to help management see which employees
are excelling and which ones need more attention and development.

Talent management technology can capture, store and analyze important data
throughout the entire lifecycle of an employee that can be utilized to improve
business processes as well as the work lives of a company’s staff. This “big
data” approach leads to better recruiting, more qualified candidates, a
shorter and more efficient hiring process, and a decrease in employee
turnover.

According to [a recent report from Capterra](https://www.capterra.com/talent-
management-software/user-research), 73% of talent management software users
stated that their system had a positive effect on the time they spend
performing HR administrative tasks. They also reported a reduction in the
amount of time spent recruiting, lower costs, and an increase in employee
engagement and satisfaction.

## **How to choose talent management software**

Shopping for a new talent management solution can be intimidating and
confusing. There are so many options available and so much to think about when
implementing new technology throughout your organization. People are reluctant
to any type of change and having to learn a new system might not go over well
with all of your staff.

Here are a few best practices that can help you choose the right TMS and get
your entire organization on board.

### **1\. Get input from your team and involve them in the final decision.**

  
In order to ensure a solution is the right fit and feel for your organization,
start with getting feedback from your entire team. Your HR team should have a
lot of input, considering the fact that they will be the ones using it the
most. But you should also discuss the decision with your entire management
team, since everyone will be involved in utilizing the system for performance
reviews, feedback, mentoring, and more.

### **2\. Think about the level of integration and specialization you need.**

  
Do you have specific or legacy programs that would need to be customized and
integrated with a new system, or could you just simply make the switch over to
an out-of-the-box solution? Are you in an industry that has to meet specific
regulations that will require special programming or a certain type of
software? Keep in mind that you might not be able to find everything you’re
looking for in one solution. You may need to consider a customized software
program built specifically for your organization and your requirements.

### **3\. Decide if you need an on-premise, cloud-based, or hybrid solution.**

  
If you have several locations, you’ll probably want to go with a cloud-based
TMS option. However, if you work with highly classified or privileged
information, a more secure on-premise application would be the best choice.
Perhaps you need a hybrid combination of both. Knowing exactly what type works
best for your organization before you start shopping for a solution will save
you a lot of time.

### **4\. Look for a solution with a detailed analytics module.**

  
You want your TMS software to be able to gather valuable information, analyze
that data, and provide you with actionable insights that can help improve
every aspect of your business. A lot of solutions come with standard analytics
as part of the package and some have an upgraded option. Spending a little
extra on software that has a built-in [big data
solution](https://www.itechart.com/solutions/big-data-bi/) will be well worth
the additional costs.

### **5\. Choose your vendor wisely.**

  
You are making a large investment in your TMS solution, so you need to know
that the vendor you choose will be there for you over the long haul. What type
of support do they offer? Is it 24/7? Do you have a trial period where you can
test the product before signing a long contract? What happens if your vendor
gets bought out by a larger company? It’s always a good idea to check vendor
references and read online reviews of other companies who have used or are
currently using the product.

## **Conclusion**

Talent management systems are not just for large enterprise businesses.
Startups and small to medium size companies can also benefit from the
automation, increased efficiencies, and analytical data provided by these
types of software solutions.

Whatever you’re looking for, rest assured that there is a TMS solution for
you. You may need a bit of customization or training, but the upfront costs
and time spent learning a new system will be well worth the investment when
you’re hiring and retaining the highest quality employees. It’s a win for
everybody.

# How Artificial Intelligence (AI) in Learning Management Systems (LMS) will
Streamline Employee Learning

If we were to believe Hollywood, artificial intelligence is poised to take
over the world and wipe out the need for humans entirely.

But the reality of AI doesn’t quite match up..

Although we’re still exploring the potential of AI, the type of AI currently
in use is commonly referred to as Narrow AI. Narrow AI focuses on performing a
specific job or task and doesn’t have unlimited learning capabilities like in
the movies.

Today..

We use artificial intelligence in the form of Alexa, Siri, Google Home, online
shopping, search recommendations, and more. If you’ve ever been automatically
tagged in a photo on Facebook that’s Facebook’s image recognition AI at work.

Artificial intelligence is at work in our lives every day without even
realizing it. It serves to make our lives easier but still requires human
input to function. Considering the [increasing use of
AI](https://www.forbes.com/sites/joemckendrick/2018/12/19/how-fast-is-
artificial-intelligence-growing-look-at-the-key-bellwethers/#532f0e17474a),
one of the greatest opportunities for AI to be realized is in [learning
management systems](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-
development/what-is-a-learning-management-system-lms/).

## What Is Artificial Intelligence?

Before we jump into the use of artificial intelligence in learning and
development, it’s important to understand what AI is. AI or artificial
intelligence simply refers to the capability machines have to learn and
process data on their own using data sets.

Once a machine learns from the data they collect, they can make “decisions” on
their own, based on the data they’ve collected.

Machine learning is simply an extension of AI and refers to machines that are
trained to analyze data and trends. These machines build their own algorithms
from the data they collect and use it to make “decisions” without human
intervention.

## Learning Management Systems

Currently, AI plays a small role in learning and development systems through
E-learning and learning management systems.

These systems are some of the best ways to help students learn because they
[increase retention up to
60%](https://www.shiftelearning.com/blog/bid/301248/15-facts-and-stats-that-
reveal-the-power-of-elearning), allow multiple students to receive instruction
at the same time, and offer opportunities for improvements and customized
education in the future.

Data gathered by your LMS through surveys, ratings, comments, and course
metrics needs to be updated by human hands. And even the best artificial
intelligence can’t make up for poorly created content.

Keeping learning and development up-to-date through LMS AI resources takes,
time and even AI needs a little human help to enhance learning and
development.

**Learn More:** **[5 Key Learning Management System (LMS) Trends in
2019](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-development/top-lms-
trends/)**

## The Future of Learning Management

Today’s intelligent learning management systems help pinpoint where students
need additional education and training as well as where you can optimize your
course content in a faster and more accurate way than you can without the
assistance of artificial intelligence.

But AI’s role is constantly expanding across every industry.

Perhaps the greatest realization for AI in the future of learning and
development is that it will help anticipate the user’s learning path and
behaviors, predict their learning needs and provide content based on how users
learn best and increase the effectiveness of e-learning and LMS courses.

## Anticipated Learning Path

As AI continues to improve in the future, it will become easier for systems to
create customized learning paths for individual users.

Transforming learning and development through an anticipated learning path
means that artificial intelligence will assess user performance and determine
which information path is best for the user.

AI with these capabilities will provide recommendations on what kinds of
information a user’s needs, much like Netflix or Amazon provides
recommendations on what shows you should watch based on your viewing behavior.

Aside from helping users find better learning paths, artificial intelligence
can also assist in learning and development by helping teaching professionals
understand what their employees need to learn.

## Opportunity Highlight

Through data pattern identification, learning management systems collect data
and statistics on students to find learning gaps and opportunities that
teachers may not have noticed or realized.

Using pattern identification, and data, artificial intelligence can help
identify opportunities to merge new ideas with previous topics to create a
well-rounded learning experience for the user. This allows administrators and
teachers to cover learning gaps they may not even realize exist.

## Course Effectiveness

Artificial intelligence can also assist learning and development efforts by
helping teachers find ways to make courses more effective. One of these ways
is through gamification. If done properly, gamification can make learning
more[ engaging](https://www.bunchball.com/blog/post/1919/how-gamification-
learning-improves-knowledge-retention) and increase information retention.

Increasing course effectiveness can also assist teachers directly by making it
easier to find opportunities to make the course more effective, fill
informational gaps, automatically grade students, help with onboarding, and
get the instruction process moving.

## Artificial Intelligence in the Future of Learning and Development

Although there are many unknowns in the future of AI, applying the tools we
have to improve the future of learning and development will help us create a
more personalized approach to our e-learning and learning management systems.

Artificial intelligence shouldn’t be looked at as a replacement of humans in
the educational process, but as a support system that allows us to take
individualized learning to the next level.

#  360factors Announces Upgraded Learning Management System (LMS) for the
Predict360 Risk and Compliance Intelligence Platform

__[AIT News Desk](https://www.aithority.com/author/ait-news-desk/) __19 Feb
2020 __[HR Technology](https://www.aithority.com/category/hrtechnology/),
[News](https://www.aithority.com/category/news/) __[Leave a
comment](https://www.aithority.com/hrtechnology/360factors-announces-upgraded-
learning-management-system-lms-for-the-predict360-risk-and-compliance-
intelligence-platform/#respond) __307 Views

[360factors, Inc.](http://www.360factors.com), the industry leader in risk and
compliance intelligence software, announced that the company has released a
major upgrade to its compliance-centric Learning Management System (LMS)
application within its [Predict360
](https://www.360factors.com/predict-360/)software platform.

Unlike standalone systems, Predict360's Learning Management application
combines a robust LMS with the ability to link training to associated
regulatory requirements, business obligations, risks, controls, audits,
issues, policies, procedures, and/or qualifications requirements to create a
single, unified GRC (Governance, Risk and Compliance) system designed
specifically for banks and financial services organizations.

 ** _AiThority.com News:_** _[Western Digital Powers Mobile Applications in
the 5G Era](https://www.aithority.com/internet-of-
things/5g-technology/western-digital-powers-mobile-applications-in-
the-5g-era/)_

The application also features a Qualification Management system that
maintains, aggregates and monitors employee qualifications. This enables
organizations to streamline the qualification process and ensure that employee
qualifications remain current by tracking employee qualifications, monitoring
qualification expirations, and maintaining the qualification history of
employees and subcontractors. When a qualification is linked to a training
course, that course can automatically be assigned to the employee or
subcontractor.

 ** _AiThority.com News:_** _[Latest Automation Trends Show Power Over
Ethernet Technology in Digital Building
Applications](https://www.aithority.com/technology/latest-automation-trends-
show-power-over-ethernet-technology-in-digital-building-applications/)_

"By upgrading our LMS architecture, we are now able to offer a faster, more
streamlined user experience," said [Carl L.
McCauley](https://www.linkedin.com/in/carlmccauley/), CEO for 360factors, Inc.
"We've recently onboarded five new bank customers and are confident this is
the most unique risk and compliance platform available for banks and financial
services organizations today."

Training plans can be created at the corporate, site and group level with
tracking and management features for online classroom, web-based training, and
ad-hoc training records. Hundreds of training content options are available
through integrated content plug-ins from banking industry partners. Customers
can also upload their own training courses.

# The Josh Bersin Academy Launches Unique Program to Help HR Professionals
Accelerate Transition to Remote Work

### Share Article

  *   *   *   *   *   * [](http://www.addthis.com/bookmark.php "Email a friend")

## Acknowledging the radical change in work practices from COVID-19, The
Remote Work Bootcamp provides a foundation for the processes, practices, and
habits to facilitate the transition to remote work.

![News
Image](//ww1.prweb.com/prfiles/2020/04/06/17032215/gI_98408_NewsImage_vcsPRAsset_3629514_98408_9aeee459-fe18-4611-ad77-4e8a3626834f_0.png)

> “While most HR organizations have ‘playbooks’ for standard business
> situations – such as a merger, an acquisition, the opening of a new
> location, even a downsizing – this situation is unlike anything we’ve
> experienced before," said Josh Bersin, global industry analyst.

OAKLAND, Calif. (PRWEB) April 07, 2020

The [Josh Bersin Academy](https://bersinacademy.com), the world’s first global
professional development academy for HR, today announced the availability of
its newest program, [The Remote Work Bootcamp](https://bersinacademy.com/the-
remote-work-bootcamp). The program, which is supplemented by 40 supporting
resources and a community for sharing and collaboration, is designed to help
HR professionals learn how to generate trust, build shared norms, foster
collaboration among teams, and deal with the unique work/life balance
challenges faced by many employees – all while working remotely.

“We now know that remote work is here to stay, yet fewer than half of
companies have clear policies and guidelines,” said Josh Bersin, global
industry analyst and dean of the Josh Bersin Academy. “While most HR
organizations have ‘playbooks’ for standard business situations – such as a
merger, an acquisition, the opening of a new location, even a downsizing –
this situation is unlike anything we’ve experienced before. HR professionals
are now involved in tool selection, equipment allocation, policies and
procedures, and the physical and mental health of employees.

“The Josh Bersin Academy is committed to supporting the HR profession tackle
the unprecedented short- and long-term challenges ahead of us. This program is
the first part of a bigger initiative we will soon be launching focused on
‘The Big Reset’ of work,” said Bersin, who recently wrote [“The Big Reset:
Making Sense of the Coronavirus Crisis.”](https://joshbersin.com/2020/03/the-
big-reset-making-sense-of-the-coronavirus-crisis/)

Prior to the COVID-19 crisis, about 29 percent of employees regularly worked
remotely, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. Today that number
is projected to double. In recent weeks, major companies, including Google,
IBM, and Apple, have mandated working from home for most employees. However,
it is estimated that up to 57% of companies have no clear policies for remote
working.

[The Remote Work Bootcamp program](https://bersinacademy.com/the-remote-work-
bootcamp) is cohort-based, with participants divided into teams for ongoing
collaboration and information sharing. The online program runs for
approximately five weeks and takes about two to three hours of total of time
to complete. The program incorporates a rich combination of key ideas,
exercises, video interviews, and challenges designed to promote discussion and
sharing with fellow team members.

The program consists of five field manuals: Remote + HR, Tools + Rules, Space
+ Routine, Trust + Relationships. The program includes video interviews with
leaders such as Rich Kaplan, general manager of employee experience and HR
services for Microsoft; Kerry Rooks, chief human resources officer, Prudential
Corporation Asia; and Gretchen Stroud, vice president of talent development,
Hilton.

In addition, the program has 40 supplemental resources – covering topics such
as working through conflicts remotely, crisis messaging, parenting hacks, and
remote leadership. Members also have access to the Academy’s community, where
professionals from around the world and across all industry segments can
collaborate and share best practices.

Information on the Academy’s membership options for individuals, which start
as low as $40 per month, can be found
[here,](https://bersinacademy.com/pricing) along with details on team and
enterprise memberships. A version of the program designed specifically for
employees is available from the Academy’s partner, Nomadic Learning,
[here.](https://nomadic.academy/welcome)

About the Josh Bersin Academy  
[The Josh Bersin Academy](https://bersinacademy.com) is the world's first
global development academy for HR and talent professionals and a
transformation agent for HR organizations. The Academy, which currently has
approximately 8,000 members, offers content-rich online programs, a carefully
curated library of tools and resources, and a global community that helps HR
and talent professionals stay current on the trends and practices needed to
drive organizational success in the modern world of work.

The Academy currently offers ten programs: People as a Competitive Advantage;
Performance Management Reimagined; The Agile Learning Organization; The HR
Technology Workshop; Wellbeing at Work; People Analytics; Voices, Values and

## How to Choose an LMS: A Comprehensive Guide

February 21, 2020

#####
[![](https://learn.g2.com/hubfs/GoSkills%20X%20G2%20How%20to%20Choose%20an%20LMS%20A%20Comprehensive%20Guide.jpeg)](/author/krystal-
tolani) by [Krystal Tolani](/author/krystal-tolani)

![](https://learn.g2.com/hubfs/iStock-500810992.jpg)

##### **Share**

[ __](https://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://learn.g2.com/how-to-
choose-an-lms)

[
__](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://learn.g2.com/how-
to-choose-an-lms)

[ __](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=https://learn.g2.com/how-to-choose-
an-
lms&text=How%20to%20Choose%20an%20LMS:%20A%20Comprehensive%20Guide%20via%20@G2dotcom)

[
__](mailto:?subject=B2B%20Marketing%20|%20G2%20Crowd&body=B2B%20Marketing%20|%20G2%20Crowd%20https://learn.g2.com/how-
to-choose-an-lms "Share by Email")

Learning management systems, or LMSes, are strategic investments.

They require time and money to set up, and provide returns by way of skilled
up talent and an improved bottom line. That is, if you choose the right one.

With hundreds of LMS providers out there, it can be daunting to pick the right
one for your company. With so many different factors at play, it’s important
to understand your company’s needs before jumping into the process.

# How to choose an LMS

Choosing an [LMS](https://www.goskills.com/Blog/What-is-an-LMS) isn’t as easy
as picking the most feature rich solution out there. In fact, doing just that
can backfire on you. A system that’s too complex can alienate admins and
learners that aren’t digital natives. Conversely, a system that’s too
simplified will hinder course creators and learning admins from living up to
their full potential.

Aside from the features, there are a number of other factors you will need to
consider when making your decision. In this article, we will go through the
steps you can take to make an informed decision.

## Spell out your training needs

Selecting a system is akin to Goldilocks’ dilemma. There isn’t a one size fits
all solution and in order to find the perfect fit you will first need to
figure out what “perfect” means in relation to your company. Mapping out your
company’s training needs is a process done best with collaboration. If you
have an existing training solution, speak to admins and a small group of
learners to find out what’s lacking.

### Who are you training?

This might be apparent to you already, but knowing who you’re training is
essential to determining how you will train and what solution you should use.

#### Age

Meeting people at their digital literacy level is key to improving engagement
rates. If your company skews older, it would be wise to opt for an LMS with
limited features and a friendly UX. A LMS that’s difficult to use can alienate
learners who have only recently become digitally literate.

If there is a millennial majority, you may want to consider a system with
gamification and social learning elements. An LMS that mimics digital
interactions millennials have outside of work makes learning an engaging
experience.

#### Size

How many people do you plan on training? A team, or the entire company? If you
plan on training a smaller group of people, you might be limited by the
solutions you can opt for. A number of learning management systems have
minimum learner requirements.

If your company is growing or has a significant turnover rate, you will have
to consider the different pricing plans as well as the mass user registration
features.

**Here are some of the pricing plans you will encounter:  **

  * **Pay-per-learner:** ideal if you have a stable number of learners and if training is mandatory
  * **Pay-per-active-user:** ideal if you have one-time training (e.g. onboarding) or if you’d like to train batches of learners over the year.
  * **Pay-as-you-go:** ideal if you’re unsure if there will be a stable demand for learning
  * **License fee:** ideal for large enterprises

#### Skills

Is everyone starting at level one, or are some learners more advanced? If
you’re training people with different skill sets, you should look into a
system that lets you segment your audience, create learning paths, or use
placement tests.

If a learner is forced to complete lessons they have already mastered, they
may not be as inclined to continue learning, However, this won’t matter if
your learners are starting from the same place. So if your objective is
compliance training, you won’t have to worry about placement functionality.
However, you will need a solution with a robust tracking system.

### What are your goals?

What do you hope to achieve through your learning and development initiatives?
When setting your goals, use the [SMART goals](/smart-goals) format to ensure
you’re being specific.

To refresh your memory, SMART stands for specific, measurable, achievable,
realistic, and time limited. So instead of “increase compliance rate”, your
goal could be “reduce time for certification from three months to two weeks.”
Breaking down your goals into smaller chunks betters your chance of achieving
them.

Help yourself with a free template to get your SMART goals in check!

[![Ready to set some SMART goals? Download FREE worksheet](https://no-
cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/4099946/2ab72641-b175-4378-973b-6036c07b29fe.png)](https://cta-
redirect.hubspot.com/cta/redirect/4099946/2ab72641-b175-4378-973b-6036c07b29fe)

As well as setting goals for the immediate future, take into consideration
your company’s goals for the next five years. Selecting an LMS that can fulfil
the training needs of today and tomorrow will save you time and money in the
long run.

### What are your technical requirements?

The key technical requirements you should be concerned with are content
(various types), support, user management, learning models, reporting,
security, and integrations.

#### Content

What type of content do you already have? What type of content do you plan on
creating in the next few years? Make a list of the file types you need
supported (e.g. [SCORM](https://www.goskills.com/Blog/What-is-scorm), PDFs,
external links, audio, video) and another list of nice-to-have supported file
types for the future.

Another technical content requirement to consider is where the content is
coming from. Some LMS have inbuilt content editors that enable admins to
create learning materials from within the platform, or a team that can help
you create custom courses from your existing materials.

#### Support

Another green flag is a robust support service. While you want your solution
to be intuitive and easy-to-use, you do want to be able to get help when you
need it. Once you have shortlisted a few providers, try contacting their
support to ensure their responses meet your standards.

#### User management

Again, depending on how many people you plan on training, registration will be
a factor you will need to consider. Will learners register themselves or will
an admin do this?

If you’re training a large group, look into systems that offer mass
registration features such as a CSV upload. If you have high turnover, an
automated data feed will cut down on admin workload. Do you have multiple
admins working on the LMS? Ensure that the system you pick allows for joint
control over the system.

#### Learning models

Another way to narrow down the search is by defining whether your training
will be exclusively online, exclusive online, or blended. If your L&D
initiatives involve instructor-led training, you will need a platform that
lets you manage schedules and locations, as well as monitor attendances.

#### Reporting

Learning and development initiatives are all about the results. How do you
plan on measuring them? Look back to the goals you created in the previous
step and note down the metrics you need to collect in order to track their
progress.

Do you need the data to be exportable? Are you more interested in group
metrics or individual reporting? Do you need the ability to customize reports?

#### Security

Security is an important part of eLearning, especially when compliance comes
into play. Learners shouldn’t be able to log into each others accounts and
their data should be kept safe.

**Some factors to think about are:**

  * Location of data storage
  * User authentication
  * Who can have access to what data

Integrations

Does your company use existing Business Intelligence or HR software? If so, is
it essential that the LMS connects to it? Answering these questions thoroughly
will give you clarity when evaluating the different solutions out there. Once
you have a definitive list of your requirements, you can start thinking about
the extra features you’d like to have.

### What are your nice-to-haves?

At this point in the LMS search, you can also ask your mini focus group
comprised of learners and admins to dream up nice-to-have features. Learning
technology is constantly evolving. Here are just a handful of extra features
you may encounter on your search for an LMS:

  * **Social learning:** this can present in a number of forms, but they all involve some social aspect. (e.g. knowledge sharing, competition)
  * **Talent management:** creation of learning paths to close skill gaps
  * **Mobile learning:** training is accessible through an app or through an adaptive platform.
  * **E-commerce:** the ability to sell the courses you create
  * **White labelling:** makes training feel like a seamless part of the learning experience. Most LMS have basic white labelling features (e.g. logo or theme colours). If you want training to feel even more seamless, you can look into adding the platform to your domain.
  * **Gamification:** like social learning, this can also take on many forms (e.g. points, rewards, leaderboards) and have a motivating effect on learners
  * **Certificates:** the ability to upload or create certificates through the platform

## Explore your options

Once you have a robust idea of your requirements, it’s time to look at your
options. You can use sites like G2 to filter by feature in order to come up
with a shortlist of LMS to pick from. With so many learning management systems
on the market, this list might be quite long.

One way to narrow the list down is by asking your peers about their
experiences with learning management systems or reading online reviews.
Remember to take notes while you’re doing this. Evaluating different solutions
is a long process and the different SaaS may start blending into one. Using an
Excel sheet to evaluate the different options and keep track of the notes
might be tedious, but will help you out down the line.

## Narrow down the list

After you’ve come up with a list of options, it’s time to narrow the list down
even further. You can do this by investigating a vendor’s track record. Have
they won awards? How many years have they been in business? Do they have a
history of iterating and advancing their product? How many businesses have
they worked with?

Awards, years in business, innovation, and experience are all green flags to
look out for. Another thing to look out for is a strong knowledge base – are
there how to articles and video tutorials available?

How does this vendor handle updates? Will you be informed well in advance?
Will you need to pay extra to be upgraded? Once you have further downsized
your list to 3-5 vendors, it’s time to take the next step.

### Request a demo

Before you request a demo, refer back to your needs training goals and come up
with a list of use cases for the LMS. Additionally, prepare a list of
questions to ask the vendor’s representative. Use this time to find out about
hidden costs, user data protection, customization, or any information you
couldn’t find in the research process. Finally, gather the relevant internal
stakeholders and let the demos commence.

### Try it yourself

The demos will have given you more clarity when choosing a platform. However,
the real test is using the software yourself. Most learning management systems
offer free trials for a week or a month. Take advantage of this by signing
yourself up for the shortlisted platforms.

List out possible scenarios and use cases and work your way through the
platforms. What does it look like for a learner trying to take a course? What
happens when you delete users? How easy is it to download reports? If things
aren’t as easy to use, take this opportunity to contact their support. Is help
available right away or do you have to wait?

If you’re having difficulty using the platform, this is not a good sign as it
will likely take your colleagues more time to master using the system. After
all this research, you’re probably an LMS whiz!

#### Conclusion

There is no one size fits all solution. If there was, there wouldn’t be so
many learning management systems out there.

When choosing an LMS, your objectives need to be clear. The more precisely
defined your needs are, the easier it will be to select the right bowl of
porridge…I mean...LMS. Finally, pick something that can grow with your
company. After all this hard work, the last thing you’re going to want to do
is repeat the process the following year, or the one after that.

**Now that you know more about[LMS
software](https://www.g2.com/categories/learning-management-system-lms) than
you ever have before, explore all available options for your needs today –
only on G2. **
